list.item: FORD, PAGE } two gentlemen dwelling at Windsor.
WILLIAM PAGE a boy, son to Page.
SIR HUGH EVANS a Welsh parson.
BARDOLPH, PISTOL, NYM } sharpers attending on Falstaff.
MISTRESS QUICKLY servant to Doctor Caius.

p.stage: Enter SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Sir Hugh, persuade me not; I will make a Star-
chamber matter of it: if he were twenty Sir John
Falstaffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow, esquire.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
In the county of Gloucester, justice of peace and
'Coram.'

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Ay, cousin Slender, and 'Custalourum.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
Ay, and 'Rato-lorum' too; and a gentleman born,
master parson; who writes himself 'Armigero,' in any
bill, warrant, quittance, or obligation, 'Armigero.'

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Ay, that I do; and have done any time these three
hundred years.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
All his successors gone before him hath done't; and
all his ancestors that come after him may: they may
give the dozen white luces in their coat.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: It is an old coat.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
SHALLOW
sp.p: The luce is the fresh fish; the salt fish is an old coat.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: I may quarter, coz.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: You may, by marrying.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Not a whit.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Yes, py'r lady; if he has a quarter of your coat,
there is but three skirts for yourself, in my
simple conjectures: but that is all one. If Sir
John Falstaff have committed disparagements unto
you, I am of the church, and will be glad to do my
benevolence to make atonements and compremises
between you.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: The council shall bear it; it is a riot.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
It is not meet the council hear a riot; there is no
fear of Got in a riot: the council, look you, shall
desire to hear the fear of Got, and not to hear a
riot; take your vizaments in that.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Ha! o' my life, if I were young again, the sword
should end it.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
It is petter that friends is the sword, and end it:
and there is also another device in my prain, which
peradventure prings goot discretions with it: there
is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master Thomas
Page, which is pretty virginity.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
Mistress Anne Page? She has brown hair, and speaks
small like a woman.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
It is that fery person for all the orld, as just as
you will desire; and seven hundred pounds of moneys,
and gold and silver, is her grandsire upon his
death's-bed—Got deliver to a joyful resurrections!
—give, when she is able to overtake seventeen years
old: it were a goot motion if we leave our pribbles
and prabbles, and desire a marriage between Master
Abraham and Mistress Anne Page.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Did her grandsire leave her seven hundred pound?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: Ay, and her father is make her a petter penny.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: I know the young gentlewoman; she has good gifts.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: Seven hundred pounds and possibilities is goot gifts.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Well, let us see honest Master Page. Is Falstaff there?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Shall I tell you a lie? I do despise a liar as I do
despise one that is false, or as I despise one that
is not true. The knight, Sir John, is there; and, I
beseech you, be ruled by your well-willers. I will
peat the door for Master Page.
What, hoa! Got pless your house here!

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Here is Got's plessing, and your friend, and Justice
Shallow; and here young Master Slender, that
peradventures shall tell you another tale, if
matters grow to your likings.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
I am glad to see your worships well.
I thank you for my venison, Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Master Page, I am glad to see you: much good do it
your good heart! I wished your venison better; it
was ill killed. How doth good Mistress Page?—and I
thank you always with my heart, la! with my heart.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
How does your fallow greyhound, sir? I heard say he
was outrun on Cotsall.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: It could not be judged, sir.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: You'll not confess, you'll not confess.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
That he will not. 'Tis your fault, 'tis your fault;
'tis a good dog.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: A cur, sir.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Sir, he's a good dog, and a fair dog: can there be
more said? he is good and fair. Is Sir John
Falstaff here?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a good
office between you.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: He hath wronged me, Master Page.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
If it be confessed, it is not redress'd: is not that
so, Master Page? He hath wronged me; indeed he
hath, at a word, he hath, believe me: Robert
Shallow, esquire, saith, he is wronged.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Here comes Sir John.

p.stage: Enter FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, NYM, and PISTOL

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Now, Master Shallow, you'll complain of me to the king?

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Knight, you have beaten my men, killed my deer, and
broke open my lodge.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: But not kissed your keeper's daughter?

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Tut, a pin! this shall be answered.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
I will answer it straight; I have done all this.
That is now answered.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: The council shall know this.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
'Twere better for you if it were known in counsel:
you'll be laughed at.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: Pauca verba, Sir John; goot worts.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Good worts! good cabbage. Slender, I broke your
head: what matter have you against me?

sp.speaker: SLENDER
BARDOLPH
sp.p: You Banbury cheese!

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Ay, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: How now, Mephostophilus!

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Ay, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p: Slice, I say! pauca, pauca: slice! that's my humour.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Where's Simple, my man? Can you tell, cousin?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Peace, I pray you. Now let us understand. There is
three umpires in this matter, as I understand; that
is, Master Page, fidelicet Master Page; and there is
myself, fidelicet myself; and the three party is,
lastly and finally, mine host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: We three, to hear it and end it between them.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Fery goot: I will make a prief of it in my note-
book; and we will afterwards ork upon the cause with
as great discreetly as we can.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Pistol!

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: He hears with ears.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
The tevil and his tam! what phrase is this, 'He
hears with ear'? why, it is affectations.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Pistol, did you pick Master Slender's purse?

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
Ay, by these gloves, did he, or I would I might
never come in mine own great chamber again else, of
seven groats in mill-sixpences, and two Edward
shovel-boards, that cost me two shilling and two
pence apiece of Yead Miller, by these gloves.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Is this true, Pistol?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: No; it is false, if it is a pick-purse.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Ha, thou mountain-foreigner! Sir John and Master mine,
I combat challenge of this latten bilbo.
Word of denial in thy labras here!
Word of denial: froth and scum, thou liest!

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: By these gloves, then, 'twas he.

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p:
Be avised, sir, and pass good humours: I will say
'marry trap' with you, if you run the nuthook's
humour on me; that is the very note of it.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
By this hat, then, he in the red face had it; for
though I cannot remember what I did when you made me
drunk, yet I am not altogether an ass.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: What say you, Scarlet and John?

sp.speaker: BARDOLPH
sp.p:
Why, sir, for my part I say the gentleman had drunk
himself out of his five sentences.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: It is his five senses: fie, what the ignorance is!

sp.speaker: BARDOLPH
sp.p:
And being fap, sir, was, as they say, cashiered; and
so conclusions passed the careires.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
Ay, you spake in Latin then too; but 'tis no
matter: I'll ne'er be drunk whilst I live again,
but in honest, civil, godly company, for this trick:
if I be drunk, I'll be drunk with those that have
the fear of God, and not with drunken knaves.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: So Got udge me, that is a virtuous mind.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: You hear all these matters denied, gentlemen; you hear it.

p.stage: Enter ANNE PAGE, with wine; MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE, following

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Nay, daughter, carry the wine in; we'll drink within.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: O heaven! this is Mistress Anne Page.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: How now, Mistress Ford!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, by my troth, you are very well met:
by your leave, good mistress.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome. Come, we have a
hot venison pasty to dinner: come, gentlemen, I hope
we shall drink down all unkindness.

p.stage: Exeunt all except SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I had rather than forty shillings I had my Book of
Songs and Sonnets here.

How now, Simple! where have you been? I must wait
on myself, must I? You have not the Book of Riddles
about you, have you?

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p:
Book of Riddles! why, did you not lend it to Alice
Shortcake upon All-hallowmas last, a fortnight
afore Michaelmas?

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Come, coz; come, coz; we stay for you. A word with
you, coz; marry, this, coz: there is, as 'twere, a
tender, a kind of tender, made afar off by Sir Hugh
here. Do you understand me?

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
Ay, sir, you shall find me reasonable; if it be so,
I shall do that that is reason.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Nay, but understand me.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: So I do, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Give ear to his motions, Master Slender: I will
description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
Nay, I will do as my cousin Shallow says: I pray
you, pardon me; he's a justice of peace in his
country, simple though I stand here.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
But that is not the question: the question is
concerning your marriage.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Ay, there's the point, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: Marry, is it; the very point of it; to Mistress Anne Page.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
Why, if it be so, I will marry her upon any
reasonable demands.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
But can you affection the 'oman? Let us command to
know that of your mouth or of your lips; for divers
philosophers hold that the lips is parcel of the
mouth. Therefore, precisely, can you carry your
good will to the maid?

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I hope, sir, I will do as it shall become one that
would do reason.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Nay, Got's lords and his ladies! you must speak
possitable, if you can carry her your desires
towards her.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: That you must. Will you, upon good dowry, marry her?

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I will do a greater thing than that, upon your
request, cousin, in any reason.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Nay, conceive me, conceive me, sweet coz: what I do
is to pleasure you, coz. Can you love the maid?

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I will marry her, sir, at your request: but if there
be no great love in the beginning, yet heaven may
decrease it upon better acquaintance, when we are
married and have more occasion to know one another;
I hope, upon familiarity will grow more contempt:
but if you say, 'Marry her,' I will marry her; that
I am freely dissolved, and dissolutely.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
It is a fery discretion answer; save the fall is in
the ort 'dissolutely:' the ort is, according to our
meaning, 'resolutely:' his meaning is good.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Ay, I think my cousin meant well.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Ay, or else I would I might be hanged, la!

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Here comes fair Mistress Anne.
Would I were young for your sake, Mistress Anne!

sp.speaker: ANNE PAGE
sp.p:
The dinner is on the table; my father desires your
worships' company.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: I will wait on him, fair Mistress Anne.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: Od's plessed will! I will not be absence at the grace.

p.stage: Exeunt SHALLOW and SIR HUGH EVANS

sp.speaker: ANNE PAGE
sp.p: Will't please your worship to come in, sir?

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: No, I thank you, forsooth, heartily; I am very well.

sp.speaker: ANNE PAGE
sp.p: The dinner attends you, sir.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I am not a-hungry, I thank you, forsooth. Go,
sirrah, for all you are my man, go wait upon my
cousin Shallow.

A justice of peace sometimes may be beholding to his
friend for a man. I keep but three men and a boy
yet, till my mother be dead: but what though? Yet I
live like a poor gentleman born.

sp.speaker: ANNE PAGE
sp.p:
I may not go in without your worship: they will not
sit till you come.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I' faith, I'll eat nothing; I thank you as much as
though I did.

sp.speaker: ANNE PAGE
sp.p: I pray you, sir, walk in.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I had rather walk here, I thank you. I bruised
my shin th' other day with playing at sword and
dagger with a master of fence; three veneys for a
dish of stewed prunes; and, by my troth, I cannot
abide the smell of hot meat since. Why do your
dogs bark so? be there bears i' the town?

sp.speaker: ANNE PAGE
sp.p: I think there are, sir; I heard them talked of.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I love the sport well but I shall as soon quarrel at
it as any man in England. You are afraid, if you see
the bear loose, are you not?

sp.speaker: ANNE PAGE
sp.p: Ay, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
That's meat and drink to me, now. I have seen
Sackerson loose twenty times, and have taken him by
the chain; but, I warrant you, the women have so
cried and shrieked at it, that it passed: but women,
indeed, cannot abide 'em; they are very ill-favored
rough things.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Come, gentle Master Slender, come; we stay for you.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: I'll eat nothing, I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: By cock and pie, you shall not choose, sir! come, come.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Nay, pray you, lead the way.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Come on, sir.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Mistress Anne, yourself shall go first.

sp.speaker: ANNE PAGE
sp.p: Not I, sir; pray you, keep on.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
I'll rather be unmannerly than troublesome.
You do yourself wrong, indeed, la!

p.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Go your ways, and ask of Doctor Caius' house which
is the way: and there dwells one Mistress Quickly,
which is in the manner of his nurse, or his dry
nurse, or his cook, or his laundry, his washer, and
his wringer.

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Nay, it is petter yet. Give her this letter; for it
is a 'oman that altogether's acquaintance with
Mistress Anne Page: and the letter is, to desire
and require her to solicit your master's desires to
Mistress Anne Page. I pray you, be gone: I will
make an end of my dinner; there's pippins and cheese to come.

p.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.
Enter FALSTAFF, Host, BARDOLPH, NYM, PISTOL, and ROBIN

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Mine host of the Garter!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: What says my bully-rook? speak scholarly and wisely.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Truly, mine host, I must turn away some of my
followers.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Discard, bully Hercules; cashier: let them wag; trot, trot.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: I sit at ten pounds a week.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Thou'rt an emperor, Caesar, Keisar, and Pheezar. I
will entertain Bardolph; he shall draw, he shall
tap: said I well, bully Hector?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Do so, good mine host.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: I have spoke; let him follow.
Let me see thee froth and lime: I am at a word; follow.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Bardolph, follow him. A tapster is a good trade:
an old cloak makes a new jerkin; a withered
serving-man a fresh tapster. Go; adieu.

sp.speaker: BARDOLPH
sp.p: It is a life that I have desired: I will thrive.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: O base Hungarian wight! wilt thou the spigot wield?

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p: He was gotten in drink: is not the humour conceited?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
I am glad I am so acquit of this tinderbox: his
thefts were too open; his filching was like an
unskilful singer; he kept not time.

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p: The good humour is to steal at a minute's rest.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
'Convey,' the wise it call. 'Steal!' foh! a fico
for the phrase!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Well, sirs, I am almost out at heels.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Why, then, let kibes ensue.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: There is no remedy; I must cony-catch; I must shift.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Young ravens must have food.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Which of you know Ford of this town?

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: I ken the wight: he is of substance good.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: My honest lads, I will tell you what I am about.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Two yards, and more.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
No quips now, Pistol! Indeed, I am in the waist two
yards about; but I am now about no waste; I am about
thrift. Briefly, I do mean to make love to Ford's
wife: I spy entertainment in her; she discourses,
she carves, she gives the leer of invitation: I
can construe the action of her familiar style; and
the hardest voice of her behavior, to be Englished
rightly, is, 'I am Sir John Falstaff's.'

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
He hath studied her will, and translated her will,
out of honesty into English.

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p: The anchor is deep: will that humour pass?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Now, the report goes she has all the rule of her
husband's purse: he hath a legion of angels.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: As many devils entertain; and 'To her, boy,' say I.

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p: The humour rises; it is good: humour me the angels.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
I have writ me here a letter to her: and here
another to Page's wife, who even now gave me good
eyes too, examined my parts with most judicious
oeillades; sometimes the beam of her view gilded my
foot, sometimes my portly belly.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Then did the sun on dunghill shine.

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p: I thank thee for that humour.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
O, she did so course o'er my exteriors with such a
greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye did
seem to scorch me up like a burning-glass! Here's
another letter to her: she bears the purse too; she
is a region in Guiana, all gold and bounty. I will
be cheater to them both, and they shall be
exchequers to me; they shall be my East and West
Indies, and I will trade to them both. Go bear thou
this letter to Mistress Page; and thou this to
Mistress Ford: we will thrive, lads, we will thrive.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side wear steel? then, Lucifer take all!

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p:
I will run no base humour: here, take the
humour-letter: I will keep the havior of reputation.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
PISTOL
sp.p:
Let vultures gripe thy guts! for gourd and fullam holds,
And high and low beguiles the rich and poor:
Tester I'll have in pouch when thou shalt lack,
Base Phrygian Turk!

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p: I have operations which be humours of revenge.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Wilt thou revenge?

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p: By welkin and her star!

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: With wit or steel?

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p:
With both the humours, I:
I will discuss the humour of this love to Page.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
And I to Ford shall eke unfold
How Falstaff, varlet vile,
His dove will prove, his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p:
My humour shall not cool: I will incense Page to
deal with poison; I will possess him with
yellowness, for the revolt of mine is dangerous:
that is my true humour.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Thou art the Mars of malecontents: I second thee; troop on.

p.stage: A room in DOCTOR CAIUS' house.
Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY, SIMPLE, and RUGBY

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
What, John Rugby! I pray thee, go to the casement,
and see if you can see my master, Master Doctor
Caius, coming. If he do, i' faith, and find any
body in the house, here will be an old abusing of
God's patience and the king's English.

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p: I'll go watch.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Go; and we'll have a posset for't soon at night, in
faith, at the latter end of a sea-coal fire.

An honest, willing, kind fellow, as ever servant
shall come in house withal, and, I warrant you, no
tell-tale nor no breed-bate: his worst fault is,
that he is given to prayer; he is something peevish
that way: but nobody but has his fault; but let
that pass. Peter Simple, you say your name is?

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p: Ay, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: And Master Slender's your master?

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p: Ay, forsooth.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Does he not wear a great round beard, like a
glover's paring-knife?

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p:
No, forsooth: he hath but a little wee face, with a
little yellow beard, a Cain-coloured beard.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: A softly-sprighted man, is he not?

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p:
Ay, forsooth: but he is as tall a man of his hands
as any is between this and his head; he hath fought
with a warrener.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
How say you? O, I should remember him: does he not
hold up his head, as it were, and strut in his gait?

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p: Yes, indeed, does he.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Well, heaven send Anne Page no worse fortune! Tell
Master Parson Evans I will do what I can for your
master: Anne is a good girl, and I wish—

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p: Out, alas! here comes my master.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
We shall all be shent. Run in here, good young man;
go into this closet: he will not stay long.

What, John Rugby! John! what, John, I say!
Go, John, go inquire for my master; I doubt
he be not well, that he comes not home.
And down, down, adown-a, &c.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
Vat is you sing? I do not like des toys. Pray you,
go and vetch me in my closet un boitier vert, a box,
a green-a box: do intend vat I speak? a green-a box.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Ay, forsooth; I'll fetch it you.

I am glad he went not in himself: if he had found
the young man, he would have been horn-mad.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
Fe, fe, fe, fe! ma foi, il fait fort chaud. Je
m'en vais a la cour—la grande affaire.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Is it this, sir?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
Oui; mette le au mon pocket: depeche, quickly. Vere
is dat knave Rugby?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: What, John Rugby! John!

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p: Here, sir!

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
You are John Rugby, and you are Jack Rugby. Come,
take-a your rapier, and come after my heel to the court.

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p: 'Tis ready, sir, here in the porch.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By my trot, I tarry too long. Od's me!
Qu'ai-j'oublie! dere is some simples in my closet,
dat I vill not for the varld I shall leave behind.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Ay me, he'll find the young man here, and be mad!

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: O diable, diable! vat is in my closet? Villain! larron!
Rugby, my rapier!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Good master, be content.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Wherefore shall I be content-a?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: The young man is an honest man.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
What shall de honest man do in my closet? dere is
no honest man dat shall come in my closet.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
I beseech you, be not so phlegmatic. Hear the truth
of it: he came of an errand to me from Parson Hugh.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Vell.

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p: Ay, forsooth; to desire her to—

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Peace, I pray you.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Peace-a your tongue. Speak-a your tale.

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p:
To desire this honest gentlewoman, your maid, to
speak a good word to Mistress Anne Page for my
master in the way of marriage.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
This is all, indeed, la! but I'll ne'er put my
finger in the fire, and need not.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
Sir Hugh send-a you? Rugby, baille me some paper.
Tarry you a little-a while.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
I am glad he is so quiet: if he
had been thoroughly moved, you should have heard him
so loud and so melancholy. But notwithstanding,
man, I'll do you your master what good I can: and
the very yea and the no is, the French doctor, my
master,—I may call him my master, look you, for I
keep his house; and I wash, wring, brew, bake,
scour, dress meat and drink, make the beds and do
all myself,—

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p:
'Tis a great charge to
come under one body's hand.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Are you avised o' that? you
shall find it a great charge: and to be up early
and down late; but notwithstanding,—to tell you in
your ear; I would have no words of it,—my master
himself is in love with Mistress Anne Page: but
notwithstanding that, I know Anne's mind,—that's
neither here nor there.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
You jack'nape, give-a this letter to Sir Hugh; by
gar, it is a shallenge: I will cut his troat in dee
park; and I will teach a scurvy jack-a-nape priest
to meddle or make. You may be gone; it is not good
you tarry here. By gar, I will cut all his two
stones; by gar, he shall not have a stone to throw
at his dog:

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Alas, he speaks but for his friend.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
It is no matter-a ver dat: do not you tell-a me
dat I shall have Anne Page for myself? By gar, I
vill kill de Jack priest; and I have appointed mine
host of de Jarteer to measure our weapon. By gar, I
will myself have Anne Page.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Sir, the maid loves you, and all shall be well. We
must give folks leave to prate: what, the good-jer!

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
Rugby, come to the court with me. By gar, if I have
not Anne Page, I shall turn your head out of my
door. Follow my heels, Rugby.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
You shall have An fool's-head of your own. No, I
know Anne's mind for that: never a woman in Windsor
knows more of Anne's mind than I do; nor can do more
than I do with her, I thank heaven.

sp.speaker: FENTON
sp.p: Who's within there? ho!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Who's there, I trow! Come near the house, I pray you.

sp.speaker: FENTON
sp.p: How now, good woman? how dost thou?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: The better that it pleases your good worship to ask.

sp.speaker: FENTON
sp.p: What news? how does pretty Mistress Anne?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
In truth, sir, and she is pretty, and honest, and
gentle; and one that is your friend, I can tell you
that by the way; I praise heaven for it.

sp.speaker: FENTON
sp.p: Shall I do any good, thinkest thou? shall I not lose my suit?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Troth, sir, all is in his hands above: but
notwithstanding, Master Fenton, I'll be sworn on a
book, she loves you. Have not your worship a wart
above your eye?

sp.speaker: FENTON
sp.p: Yes, marry, have I; what of that?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Well, thereby hangs a tale: good faith, it is such
another Nan; but, I detest, an honest maid as ever
broke bread: we had an hour's talk of that wart. I
shall never laugh but in that maid's company! But
indeed she is given too much to allicholy and
musing: but for you—well, go to.

sp.speaker: FENTON
sp.p:
Well, I shall see her to-day. Hold, there's money
for thee; let me have thy voice in my behalf: if
thou seest her before me, commend me.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Will I? i'faith, that we will; and I will tell your
worship more of the wart the next time we have
confidence; and of other wooers.

sp.speaker: FENTON
sp.p: Well, farewell; I am in great haste now.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Farewell to your worship.

p.stage: Enter MISTRESS PAGE, with a letter

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
What, have I scaped love-letters in the holiday-
time of my beauty, and am I now a subject for them?
Let me see.

'Ask me no reason why I love you; for though
Love use Reason for his physician, he admits him
not for his counsellor. You are not young, no more
am I; go to then, there's sympathy: you are merry,
so am I; ha, ha! then there's more sympathy: you
love sack, and so do I; would you desire better
sympathy? Let it suffice thee, Mistress Page,—at
the least, if the love of soldier can suffice,—
that I love thee. I will not say, pity me; 'tis
not a soldier-like phrase: but I say, love me. By me,
Thine own true knight,
By day or night,
Or any kind of light,
With all his might
For thee to fight, JOHN FALSTAFF'
What a Herod of Jewry is this! O wicked
world! One that is well-nigh worn to pieces with
age to show himself a young gallant! What an
unweighed behavior hath this Flemish drunkard
picked—with the devil's name!—out of my
conversation, that he dares in this manner assay me?
Why, he hath not been thrice in my company! What
should I say to him? I was then frugal of my
mirth: Heaven forgive me! Why, I'll exhibit a bill
in the parliament for the putting down of men. How
shall I be revenged on him? for revenged I will be,
as sure as his guts are made of puddings.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Mistress Page! trust me, I was going to your house.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
And, trust me, I was coming to you. You look very
ill.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Nay, I'll ne'er believe that; I have to show to the contrary.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Faith, but you do, in my mind.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Well, I do then; yet I say I could show you to the
contrary. O Mistress Page, give me some counsel!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: What's the matter, woman?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
O woman, if it were not for one trifling respect, I
could come to such honour!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Hang the trifle, woman! take the honour. What is
it? dispense with trifles; what is it?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
If I would but go to hell for an eternal moment or so,
I could be knighted.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
What? thou liest! Sir Alice Ford! These knights
will hack; and so thou shouldst not alter the
article of thy gentry.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
We burn daylight: here, read, read; perceive how I
might be knighted. I shall think the worse of fat
men, as long as I have an eye to make difference of
men's liking: and yet he would not swear; praised
women's modesty; and gave such orderly and
well-behaved reproof to all uncomeliness, that I
would have sworn his disposition would have gone to
the truth of his words; but they do no more adhere
and keep place together than the Hundredth Psalm to
the tune of 'Green Sleeves.' What tempest, I trow,
threw this whale, with so many tuns of oil in his
belly, ashore at Windsor? How shall I be revenged
on him? I think the best way were to entertain him
with hope, till the wicked fire of lust have melted
him in his own grease. Did you ever hear the like?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Letter for letter, but that the name of Page and
Ford differs! To thy great comfort in this mystery
of ill opinions, here's the twin-brother of thy
letter: but let thine inherit first; for, I
protest, mine never shall. I warrant he hath a
thousand of these letters, writ with blank space for
different names—sure, more,—and these are of the
second edition: he will print them, out of doubt;
for he cares not what he puts into the press, when
he would put us two. I had rather be a giantess,
and lie under Mount Pelion. Well, I will find you
twenty lascivious turtles ere one chaste man.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Why, this is the very same; the very hand, the very
words. What doth he think of us?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Nay, I know not: it makes me almost ready to
wrangle with mine own honesty. I'll entertain
myself like one that I am not acquainted withal;
for, sure, unless he know some strain in me, that I
know not myself, he would never have boarded me in this fury.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
'Boarding,' call you it? I'll be sure to keep him
above deck.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
So will I
if he come under my hatches, I'll never
to sea again. Let's be revenged on him: let's
appoint him a meeting; give him a show of comfort in
his suit and lead him on with a fine-baited delay,
till he hath pawned his horses to mine host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Nay, I will consent to act any villany against him,
that may not sully the chariness of our honesty. O,
that my husband saw this letter! it would give
eternal food to his jealousy.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: You are the happier woman.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Let's consult together against this greasy knight.
Come hither.

p.stage: Enter FORD with PISTOL, and PAGE with NYM

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Well, I hope it be not so.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Hope is a curtal dog in some affairs:
Sir John affects thy wife.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Why, sir, my wife is not young.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
FORD
sp.p: Love my wife!

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
With liver burning hot. Prevent, or go thou,
Like Sir Actaeon he, with Ringwood at thy heels:
O, odious is the name!

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: What name, sir?

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
The horn, I say. Farewell.
Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night:
Take heed, ere summer comes or cuckoo-birds do sing.
Away, Sir Corporal Nym!
Believe it, Page; he speaks sense.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: I will be patient; I will find out this.

sp.speaker: NYM
sp.p:
And this is true; I like not the humour
of lying. He hath wronged me in some humours: I
should have borne the humoured letter to her; but I
have a sword and it shall bite upon my necessity.
He loves your wife; there's the short and the long.
My name is Corporal Nym; I speak and I avouch; 'tis
true: my name is Nym and Falstaff loves your wife.
Adieu. I love not the humour of bread and cheese,
and there's the humour of it. Adieu.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
'The humour of it,' quoth a'! here's a fellow
frights English out of his wits.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: I will seek out Falstaff.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: I never heard such a drawling, affecting rogue.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: If I do find it: well.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
I will not believe such a Cataian, though the priest
o' the town commended him for a true man.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: 'Twas a good sensible fellow: well.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: How now, Meg!

p.stage: MISTRESS PAGE and MISTRESS FORD come forward

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Whither go you, George? Hark you.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: How now, sweet Frank! why art thou melancholy?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: I melancholy! I am not melancholy. Get you home, go.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Faith, thou hast some crotchets in thy head. Now,
will you go, Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Have with you. You'll come to dinner, George.

Look who comes yonder: she shall be our messenger
to this paltry knight.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Trust me, I thought on her:
she'll fit it.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: You are come to see my daughter Anne?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Ay, forsooth; and, I pray, how does good Mistress Anne?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Go in with us and see: we have an hour's talk with
you.

p.stage: Exeunt MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and MISTRESS QUICKLY

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: How now, Master Ford!

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: You heard what this knave told me, did you not?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Yes: and you heard what the other told me?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Do you think there is truth in them?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Hang 'em, slaves! I do not think the knight would
offer it: but these that accuse him in his intent
towards our wives are a yoke of his discarded men;
very rogues, now they be out of service.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Were they his men?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Marry, were they.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I like it never the better for that. Does he lie at
the Garter?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Ay, marry, does he. If he should intend this voyage
towards my wife, I would turn her loose to him; and
what he gets more of her than sharp words, let it
lie on my head.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I do not misdoubt my wife; but I would be loath to
turn them together. A man may be too confident: I
would have nothing lie on my head: I cannot be thus satisfied.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Look where my ranting host of the Garter comes:
there is either liquor in his pate or money in his
purse when he looks so merrily.
How now, mine host!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
How now, bully-rook! thou'rt a gentleman.
Cavaleiro-justice, I say!

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
I follow, mine host, I follow. Good even and
twenty, good Master Page! Master Page, will you go
with us? we have sport in hand.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Tell him, cavaleiro-justice; tell him, bully-rook.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Sir, there is a fray to be fought between Sir Hugh
the Welsh priest and Caius the French doctor.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Good mine host o' the Garter, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: What sayest thou, my bully-rook?

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
Host
sp.p:
Hast thou no suit against my knight, my
guest-cavaleire?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
None, I protest: but I'll give you a pottle of
burnt sack to give me recourse to him and tell him
my name is Brook; only for a jest.

sp.speaker: Host
SHALLOW
sp.p: Have with you, mine host.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
I have heard the Frenchman hath good skill in
his rapier.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Tut, sir, I could have told you more. In these times
you stand on distance, your passes, stoccadoes, and
I know not what: 'tis the heart, Master Page; 'tis
here, 'tis here. I have seen the time, with my long
sword I would have made you four tall fellows skip like rats.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Here, boys, here, here! shall we wag?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Have with you. I would rather hear them scold than fight.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Though Page be a secure fool, an stands so firmly
on his wife's frailty, yet I cannot put off my
opinion so easily: she was in his company at Page's
house; and what they made there, I know not. Well,
I will look further into't: and I have a disguise
to sound Falstaff. If I find her honest, I lose not
my labour; if she be otherwise, 'tis labour well bestowed.

p.stage: A room in the Garter Inn.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: I will not lend thee a penny.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
Why, then the world's mine oyster.
Which I with sword will open.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Not a penny. I have been content, sir, you should
lay my countenance to pawn; I have grated upon my
good friends for three reprieves for you and your
coach-fellow Nym; or else you had looked through
the grate, like a geminy of baboons. I am damned in
hell for swearing to gentlemen my friends, you were
good soldiers and tall fellows; and when Mistress
Bridget lost the handle of her fan, I took't upon
mine honour thou hadst it not.

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: Didst not thou share? hadst thou not fifteen pence?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Reason, you rogue, reason: thinkest thou I'll
endanger my soul gratis? At a word, hang no more
about me, I am no gibbet for you. Go. A short knife
and a throng! To your manor of Pickt-hatch! Go.
You'll not bear a letter for me, you rogue! you
stand upon your honour! Why, thou unconfinable
baseness, it is as much as I can do to keep the
terms of my honour precise: I, I, I myself
sometimes, leaving the fear of God on the left hand
and hiding mine honour in my necessity, am fain to
shuffle, to hedge and to lurch; and yet you, rogue,
will ensconce your rags, your cat-a-mountain
looks, your red-lattice phrases, and your
bold-beating oaths, under the shelter of your
honour! You will not do it, you!

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p: I do relent: what would thou more of man?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Sir, here's a woman would speak with you.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Let her approach.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Give your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Good morrow, good wife.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Not so, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Good maid, then.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
I'll be sworn,
As my mother was, the first hour I was born.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: I do believe the swearer. What with me?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Shall I vouchsafe your worship a word or two?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Two thousand, fair woman: and I'll vouchsafe thee
the hearing.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
There is one Mistress Ford, sir:—I pray, come a
little nearer this ways:—I myself dwell with master
Doctor Caius,—

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Well, on: Mistress Ford, you say,—

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Your worship says very true: I pray your worship,
come a little nearer this ways.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
I warrant thee, nobody hears; mine own people, mine
own people.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Are they so? God bless them and make them his servants!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Well, Mistress Ford; what of her?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Why, sir, she's a good creature. Lord Lord! your
worship's a wanton! Well, heaven forgive you and all
of us, I pray!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Mistress Ford; come, Mistress Ford,—

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Marry, this is the short and the long of it; you
have brought her into such a canaries as 'tis
wonderful. The best courtier of them all, when the
court lay at Windsor, could never have brought her
to such a canary. Yet there has been knights, and
lords, and gentlemen, with their coaches, I warrant
you, coach after coach, letter after letter, gift
after gift; smelling so sweetly, all musk, and so
rushling, I warrant you, in silk and gold; and in
such alligant terms; and in such wine and sugar of
the best and the fairest, that would have won any
woman's heart; and, I warrant you, they could never
get an eye-wink of her: I had myself twenty angels
given me this morning; but I defy all angels, in
any such sort, as they say, but in the way of
honesty: and, I warrant you, they could never get
her so much as sip on a cup with the proudest of
them all: and yet there has been earls, nay, which
is more, pensioners; but, I warrant you, all is one with her.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
But what says she to me? be brief, my good
she-Mercury.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Marry, she hath received your letter, for the which
she thanks you a thousand times; and she gives you
to notify that her husband will be absence from his
house between ten and eleven.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Ten and eleven?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Ay, forsooth; and then you may come and see the
picture, she says, that you wot of: Master Ford,
her husband, will be from home. Alas! the sweet
woman leads an ill life with him: he's a very
jealousy man: she leads a very frampold life with
him, good heart.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Ten and eleven. Woman, commend me to her; I will
not fail her.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Why, you say well. But I have another messenger to
your worship. Mistress Page hath her hearty
commendations to you too: and let me tell you in
your ear, she's as fartuous a civil modest wife, and
one, I tell you, that will not miss you morning nor
evening prayer, as any is in Windsor, whoe'er be the
other: and she bade me tell your worship that her
husband is seldom from home; but she hopes there
will come a time. I never knew a woman so dote upon
a man: surely I think you have charms, la; yes, in truth.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Not I, I assure thee: setting the attractions of my
good parts aside I have no other charms.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p: Blessing on your heart for't!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
But, I pray thee, tell me this: has Ford's wife and
Page's wife acquainted each other how they love me?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
That were a jest indeed! they have not so little
grace, I hope: that were a trick indeed! but
Mistress Page would desire you to send her your
little page, of all loves: her husband has a
marvellous infection to the little page; and truly
Master Page is an honest man. Never a wife in
Windsor leads a better life than she does: do what
she will, say what she will, take all, pay all, go
to bed when she list, rise when she list, all is as
she will: and truly she deserves it; for if there
be a kind woman in Windsor, she is one. You must
send her your page; no remedy.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Why, I will.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
sp.p:
Nay, but do so, then: and, look you, he may come and
go between you both; and in any case have a
nay-word, that you may know one another's mind, and
the boy never need to understand any thing; for
'tis not good that children should know any
wickedness: old folks, you know, have discretion,
as they say, and know the world.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Fare thee well: commend me to them both: there's
my purse; I am yet thy debtor. Boy, go along with
this woman.
This news distracts me!

sp.speaker: PISTOL
sp.p:
This punk is one of Cupid's carriers:
Clap on more sails; pursue; up with your fights:
Give fire: she is my prize, or ocean whelm them all!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Sayest thou so, old Jack? go thy ways; I'll make
more of thy old body than I have done. Will they
yet look after thee? Wilt thou, after the expense
of so much money, be now a gainer? Good body, I
thank thee. Let them say 'tis grossly done; so it be
fairly done, no matter.

sp.speaker: BARDOLPH
sp.p:
Sir John, there's one Master Brook below would fain
speak with you, and be acquainted with you; and hath
sent your worship a morning's draught of sack.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Brook is his name?

sp.speaker: BARDOLPH
sp.p: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Call him in.

Such Brooks are welcome to me, that o'erflow such
liquor. Ah, ha! Mistress Ford and Mistress Page
have I encompassed you? go to; via!

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Bless you, sir!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: And you, sir! Would you speak with me?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I make bold to press with so little preparation upon
you.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: You're welcome. What's your will? Give us leave, drawer.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Sir, I am a gentleman that have spent much; my name is Brook.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Good Master Brook, I desire more acquaintance of you.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Good Sir John, I sue for yours: not to charge you;
for I must let you understand I think myself in
better plight for a lender than you are: the which
hath something embolden'd me to this unseasoned
intrusion; for they say, if money go before, all
ways do lie open.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Money is a good soldier, sir, and will on.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Troth, and I have a bag of money here troubles me:
if you will help to bear it, Sir John, take all, or
half, for easing me of the carriage.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Sir, I know not how I may deserve to be your porter.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: I will tell you, sir, if you will give me the hearing.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Speak, good Master Brook: I shall be glad to be
your servant.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Sir, I hear you are a scholar,—I will be brief
with you,—and you have been a man long known to me,
though I had never so good means, as desire, to make
myself acquainted with you. I shall discover a
thing to you, wherein I must very much lay open mine
own imperfection: but, good Sir John, as you have
one eye upon my follies, as you hear them unfolded,
turn another into the register of your own; that I
may pass with a reproof the easier, sith you
yourself know how easy it is to be such an offender.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Very well, sir; proceed.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
There is a gentlewoman in this town; her husband's
name is Ford.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I have long loved her, and, I protest to you,
bestowed much on her; followed her with a doting
observance; engrossed opportunities to meet her;
fee'd every slight occasion that could but niggardly
give me sight of her; not only bought many presents
to give her, but have given largely to many to know
what she would have given; briefly, I have pursued
her as love hath pursued me; which hath been on the
wing of all occasions. But whatsoever I have
merited, either in my mind or, in my means, meed,
I am sure, I have received none; unless experience
be a jewel that I have purchased at an infinite
rate, and that hath taught me to say this:
'Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues;
Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.'

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Have you received no promise of satisfaction at her hands?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Have you importuned her to such a purpose?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Of what quality was your love, then?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Like a fair house built on another man's ground; so
that I have lost my edifice by mistaking the place
where I erected it.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: To what purpose have you unfolded this to me?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
When I have told you that, I have told you all.
Some say, that though she appear honest to me, yet in
other places she enlargeth her mirth so far that
there is shrewd construction made of her. Now, Sir
John, here is the heart of my purpose: you are a
gentleman of excellent breeding, admirable
discourse, of great admittance, authentic in your
place and person, generally allowed for your many
war-like, court-like, and learned preparations.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: O, sir!

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Believe it, for you know it. There is money; spend
it, spend it; spend more; spend all I have; only
give me so much of your time in exchange of it, as
to lay an amiable siege to the honesty of this
Ford's wife: use your art of wooing; win her to
consent to you: if any man may, you may as soon as
any.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Would it apply well to the vehemency of your
affection, that I should win what you would enjoy?
Methinks you prescribe to yourself very preposterously.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
O, understand my drift. She dwells so securely on
the excellency of her honour, that the folly of my
soul dares not present itself: she is too bright to
be looked against. Now, could I could come to her
with any detection in my hand, my desires had
instance and argument to commend themselves: I
could drive her then from the ward of her purity,
her reputation, her marriage-vow, and a thousand
other her defences, which now are too too strongly
embattled against me. What say you to't, Sir John?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Master Brook, I will first make bold with your
money; next, give me your hand; and last, as I am a
gentleman, you shall, if you will, enjoy Ford's wife.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: O good sir!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: I say you shall.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Want no money, Sir John; you shall want none.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Want no Mistress Ford, Master Brook; you shall want
none. I shall be with her, I may tell you, by her
own appointment; even as you came in to me, her
assistant or go-between parted from me: I say I
shall be with her between ten and eleven; for at
that time the jealous rascally knave her husband
will be forth. Come you to me at night; you shall
know how I speed.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I am blest in your acquaintance. Do you know Ford,
sir?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Hang him, poor cuckoldly knave! I know him not:
yet I wrong him to call him poor; they say the
jealous wittolly knave hath masses of money; for the
which his wife seems to me well-favored. I will
use her as the key of the cuckoldly rogue's coffer;
and there's my harvest-home.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might avoid him
if you saw him.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Hang him, mechanical salt-butter rogue! I will
stare him out of his wits; I will awe him with my
cudgel: it shall hang like a meteor o'er the
cuckold's horns. Master Brook, thou shalt know I
will predominate over the peasant, and thou shalt
lie with his wife. Come to me soon at night.
Ford's a knave, and I will aggravate his style;
thou, Master Brook, shalt know him for knave and
cuckold. Come to me soon at night.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
What a damned Epicurean rascal is this! My heart is
ready to crack with impatience. Who says this is
improvident jealousy? my wife hath sent to him; the
hour is fixed; the match is made. Would any man
have thought this? See the hell of having a false
woman! My bed shall be abused, my coffers
ransacked, my reputation gnawn at; and I shall not
only receive this villanous wrong, but stand under
the adoption of abominable terms, and by him that
does me this wrong. Terms! names! Amaimon sounds
well; Lucifer, well; Barbason, well; yet they are
devils' additions, the names of fiends: but
Cuckold! Wittol!—Cuckold! the devil himself hath
not such a name. Page is an ass, a secure ass: he
will trust his wife; he will not be jealous. I will
rather trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh
the Welshman with my cheese, an Irishman with my
aqua-vitae bottle, or a thief to walk my ambling
gelding, than my wife with herself; then she plots,
then she ruminates, then she devises; and what they
think in their hearts they may effect, they will
break their hearts but they will effect. God be
praised for my jealousy! Eleven o'clock the hour.
I will prevent this, detect my wife, be revenged on
Falstaff, and laugh at Page. I will about it;
better three hours too soon than a minute too late.
Fie, fie, fie! cuckold! cuckold! cuckold!

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Jack Rugby!

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Vat is de clock, Jack?

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p: 'Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh promised to meet.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By gar, he has save his soul, dat he is no come; he
has pray his Pible well, dat he is no come: by gar,
Jack Rugby, he is dead already, if he be come.

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p:
He is wise, sir; he knew your worship would kill
him, if he came.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By gar, de herring is no dead so as I vill kill him.
Take your rapier, Jack; I vill tell you how I vill kill him.

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p: Alas, sir, I cannot fence.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Villany, take your rapier.

sp.speaker: RUGBY
sp.p: Forbear; here's company.

p.stage: Enter Host, SHALLOW, SLENDER, and PAGE

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Bless thee, bully doctor!

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Save you, Master Doctor Caius!

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Now, good master doctor!

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Give you good morrow, sir.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Vat be all you, one, two, tree, four, come for?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to see thee
traverse; to see thee here, to see thee there; to
see thee pass thy punto, thy stock, thy reverse, thy
distance, thy montant. Is he dead, my Ethiopian? is
he dead, my Francisco? ha, bully! What says my
AEsculapius? my Galen? my heart of elder? ha! is
he dead, bully stale? is he dead?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By gar, he is de coward Jack priest of de vorld; he
is not show his face.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Thou art a Castalion-King-Urinal. Hector of Greece, my boy!

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
I pray you, bear vitness that me have stay six or
seven, two, tree hours for him, and he is no come.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
He is the wiser man, master doctor: he is a curer of
souls, and you a curer of bodies; if you should
fight, you go against the hair of your professions.
Is it not true, Master Page?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Master Shallow, you have yourself been a great
fighter, though now a man of peace.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Bodykins, Master Page, though I now be old and of
the peace, if I see a sword out, my finger itches to
make one. Though we are justices and doctors and
churchmen, Master Page, we have some salt of our
youth in us; we are the sons of women, Master Page.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: 'Tis true, Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
It will be found so, Master Page. Master Doctor
Caius, I am come to fetch you home. I am sworn of
the peace: you have showed yourself a wise
physician, and Sir Hugh hath shown himself a wise
and patient churchman. You must go with me, master doctor.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Pardon, guest-justice. A word, Mounseur Mockwater.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Mock-vater! vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Mock-water, in our English tongue, is valour, bully.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By gar, den, I have as mush mock-vater as de
Englishman. Scurvy jack-dog priest! by gar, me
vill cut his ears.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: He will clapper-claw thee tightly, bully.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Clapper-de-claw! vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: That is, he will make thee amends.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By gar, me do look he shall clapper-de-claw me;
for, by gar, me vill have it.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: And I will provoke him to't, or let him wag.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Me tank you for dat.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
And, moreover, bully,—but first, master guest, and
Master Page, and eke Cavaleiro Slender, go you
through the town to Frogmore.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
He is there: see what humour he is in; and I will
bring the doctor about by the fields. Will it do well?

sp.speaker: PAGE, SHALLOW, Slender
sp.p: We will do it.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By gar, me vill kill de priest; for he speak for a
jack-an-ape to Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Let him die: sheathe thy impatience, throw cold
water on thy choler: go about the fields with me
through Frogmore: I will bring thee where Mistress
Anne Page is, at a farm-house a-feasting; and thou
shalt woo her. Cried I aim? said I well?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
Host
sp.p:
For the which I will be thy adversary toward Anne
Page. Said I well?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: By gar, 'tis good; vell said.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Let us wag, then.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Come at my heels, Jack Rugby.

p.stage: Enter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
I pray you now, good master Slender's serving-man,
and friend Simple by your name, which way have you
looked for Master Caius, that calls himself doctor of physic?

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p:
Marry, sir, the pittie-ward, the park-ward, every
way; old Windsor way, and every way but the town
way.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
I most fehemently desire you you will also look that
way.

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
'Pless my soul, how full of chollors I am, and
trempling of mind! I shall be glad if he have
deceived me. How melancholies I am! I will knog
his urinals about his knave's costard when I have
good opportunities for the ork. 'Pless my soul!

To shallow rivers, to whose falls
Melodious birds sings madrigals;
There will we make our peds of roses,
And a thousand fragrant posies.
To shallow—
Mercy on me! I have a great dispositions to cry.

Melodious birds sing madrigals—
When as I sat in Pabylon—
And a thousand vagram posies.
To shallow &c.

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p: Yonder he is coming, this way, Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: He's welcome.

To shallow rivers, to whose falls-
Heaven prosper the right! What weapons is he?

sp.speaker: SIMPLE
sp.p:
No weapons, sir. There comes my master, Master
Shallow, and another gentleman, from Frogmore, over
the stile, this way.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: Pray you, give me my gown; or else keep it in your arms.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
How now, master Parson! Good morrow, good Sir Hugh.
Keep a gamester from the dice, and a good student
from his book, and it is wonderful.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: Ah, sweet Anne Page!

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: 'Save you, good Sir Hugh!

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: 'Pless you from his mercy sake, all of you!

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
What, the sword and the word! do you study them
both, master parson?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
And youthful still! in your doublet and hose this
raw rheumatic day!

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: There is reasons and causes for it.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: We are come to you to do a good office, master parson.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: Fery well: what is it?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Yonder is a most reverend gentleman, who, belike
having received wrong by some person, is at most
odds with his own gravity and patience that ever you
saw.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
I have lived fourscore years and upward; I never
heard a man of his place, gravity and learning, so
wide of his own respect.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
I think you know him; Master Doctor Caius, the
renowned French physician.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Got's will, and his passion of my heart! I had as
lief you would tell me of a mess of porridge.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and Galen,
—and he is a knave besides; a cowardly knave as you
would desires to be acquainted withal.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: I warrant you, he's the man should fight with him.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: O sweet Anne Page!

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
It appears so by his weapons. Keep them asunder:
here comes Doctor Caius.

p.stage: Enter Host, DOCTOR CAIUS, and RUGBY

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Nay, good master parson, keep in your weapon.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: So do you, good master doctor.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Disarm them, and let them question: let them keep
their limbs whole and hack our English.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
I pray you, let-a me speak a word with your ear.
Vherefore vill you not meet-a me?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Pray you, use your patience:
in good time.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: By gar, you are de coward, de Jack dog, John ape.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
Pray you let us not be
laughing-stocks to other men's humours; I desire you
in friendship, and I will one way or other make you amends.

I will knog your urinals about your knave's cockscomb
for missing your meetings and appointments.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
Diable! Jack Rugby,—mine host de Jarteer,—have I
not stay for him to kill him? have I not, at de place
I did appoint?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
As I am a Christians soul now, look you, this is the
place appointed: I'll be judgement by mine host of
the Garter.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaul, French and Welsh,
soul-curer and body-curer!

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Ay, dat is very good; excellent.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Peace, I say! hear mine host of the Garter. Am I
politic? am I subtle? am I a Machiavel? Shall I
lose my doctor? no; he gives me the potions and the
motions. Shall I lose my parson, my priest, my Sir
Hugh? no; he gives me the proverbs and the
no-verbs. Give me thy hand, terrestrial; so. Give me
thy hand, celestial; so. Boys of art, I have
deceived you both; I have directed you to wrong
places: your hearts are mighty, your skins are
whole, and let burnt sack be the issue. Come, lay
their swords to pawn. Follow me, lads of peace;
follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: Trust me, a mad host. Follow, gentlemen, follow.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: O sweet Anne Page!

p.stage: Exeunt SHALLOW, SLENDER, PAGE, and Host

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
Ha, do I perceive dat? have you make-a de sot of
us, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p:
This is well; he has made us his vlouting-stog. I
desire you that we may be friends; and let us knog
our prains together to be revenge on this same
scall, scurvy cogging companion, the host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By gar, with all my heart. He promise to bring me
where is Anne Page; by gar, he deceive me too.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: Well, I will smite his noddles. Pray you, follow.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Nay, keep your way, little gallant; you were wont to
be a follower, but now you are a leader. Whether
had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your master's heels?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p:
I had rather, forsooth, go before you like a man
than follow him like a dwarf.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: O, you are a flattering boy: now I see you'll be a courtier.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Well met, Mistress Page. Whither go you?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Truly, sir, to see your wife. Is she at home?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Ay; and as idle as she may hang together, for want
of company. I think, if your husbands were dead,
you two would marry.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Be sure of that,—two other husbands.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Where had you this pretty weather-cock?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
I cannot tell what the dickens his name is my
husband had him of. What do you call your knight's
name, sirrah?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Sir John Falstaff.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Sir John Falstaff!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
He, he; I can never hit on's name. There is such a
league between my good man and he! Is your wife at
home indeed?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Indeed she is.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: By your leave, sir: I am sick till I see her.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Has Page any brains? hath he any eyes? hath he any
thinking? Sure, they sleep; he hath no use of them.
Why, this boy will carry a letter twenty mile, as
easy as a cannon will shoot point-blank twelve
score. He pieces out his wife's inclination; he
gives her folly motion and advantage: and now she's
going to my wife, and Falstaff's boy with her. A
man may hear this shower sing in the wind. And
Falstaff's boy with her! Good plots, they are laid;
and our revolted wives share damnation together.
Well; I will take him, then torture my wife, pluck
the borrowed veil of modesty from the so seeming
Mistress Page, divulge Page himself for a secure and
wilful Actaeon; and to these violent proceedings all
my neighbours shall cry aim.

The clock gives me my cue, and my assurance bids me
search: there I shall find Falstaff: I shall be
rather praised for this than mocked; for it is as
positive as the earth is firm that Falstaff is
there: I will go.

p.stage: Enter PAGE, SHALLOW, SLENDER, Host, SIR HUGH EVANS, DOCTOR CAIUS, and RUGBY

sp.speaker: SHALLOW, PAGE, &C.
sp.p: Well met, Master Ford.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Trust me, a good knot: I have good cheer at home;
and I pray you all go with me.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p: I must excuse myself, Master Ford.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p:
And so must I, sir: we have appointed to dine with
Mistress Anne, and I would not break with her for
more money than I'll speak of.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
We have lingered about a match between Anne Page and
my cousin Slender, and this day we shall have our answer.

sp.speaker: SLENDER
sp.p: I hope I have your good will, father Page.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
You have, Master Slender; I stand wholly for you:
but my wife, master doctor, is for you altogether.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
Ay, be-gar; and de maid is love-a me: my nursh-a
Quickly tell me so mush.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
What say you to young Master Fenton? he capers, he
dances, he has eyes of youth, he writes verses, he
speaks holiday, he smells April and May: he will
carry't, he will carry't; 'tis in his buttons; he
will carry't.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Not by my consent, I promise you. The gentleman is
of no having: he kept company with the wild prince
and Poins; he is of too high a region; he knows too
much. No, he shall not knit a knot in his fortunes
with the finger of my substance: if he take her,
let him take her simply; the wealth I have waits on
my consent, and my consent goes not that way.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I beseech you heartily, some of you go home with me
to dinner: besides your cheer, you shall have
sport; I will show you a monster. Master doctor,
you shall go; so shall you, Master Page; and you, Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: SHALLOW
sp.p:
Well, fare you well: we shall have the freer wooing
at Master Page's.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p: Go home, John Rugby; I come anon.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Farewell, my hearts: I will to my honest knight
Falstaff, and drink canary with him.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I think I shall drink in pipe wine first
with him; I'll make him dance. Will you go, gentles?

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Have with you to see this monster.

p.stage: Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: What, John! What, Robert!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Quickly, quickly! is the buck-basket—

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: I warrant. What, Robin, I say!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Here, set it down.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Give your men the charge; we must be brief.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Marry, as I told you before, John and Robert, be
ready here hard by in the brew-house: and when I
suddenly call you, come forth, and without any pause
or staggering take this basket on your shoulders:
that done, trudge with it in all haste, and carry
it among the whitsters in Datchet-mead, and there
empty it in the muddy ditch close by the Thames side.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: You will do it?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
I ha' told them over and over; they lack no
direction. Be gone, and come when you are called.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Here comes little Robin.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: How now, my eyas-musket! what news with you?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p:
My master, Sir John, is come in at your back-door,
Mistress Ford, and requests your company.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: You little Jack-a-Lent, have you been true to us?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p:
Ay, I'll be sworn. My master knows not of your
being here and hath threatened to put me into
everlasting liberty if I tell you of it; for he
swears he'll turn me away.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Thou'rt a good boy: this secrecy of thine shall be
a tailor to thee and shall make thee a new doublet
and hose. I'll go hide me.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Do so. Go tell thy master I am alone.
Mistress Page, remember you your cue.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: I warrant thee; if I do not act it, hiss me.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Go to, then: we'll use this unwholesome humidity,
this gross watery pumpion; we'll teach him to know
turtles from jays.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Have I caught thee, my heavenly jewel? Why, now let
me die, for I have lived long enough: this is the
period of my ambition: O this blessed hour!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: O sweet Sir John!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate,
Mistress Ford. Now shall I sin in my wish: I would
thy husband were dead: I'll speak it before the
best lord; I would make thee my lady.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: I your lady, Sir John! alas, I should be a pitiful lady!

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Let the court of France show me such another. I see
how thine eye would emulate the diamond: thou hast
the right arched beauty of the brow that becomes the
ship-tire, the tire-valiant, or any tire of
Venetian admittance.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
A plain kerchief, Sir John: my brows become nothing
else; nor that well neither.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
By the Lord, thou art a traitor to say so: thou
wouldst make an absolute courtier; and the firm
fixture of thy foot would give an excellent motion
to thy gait in a semi-circled farthingale. I see
what thou wert, if Fortune thy foe were not, Nature
thy friend. Come, thou canst not hide it.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Believe me, there is no such thing in me.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
What made me love thee? let that persuade thee
there's something extraordinary in thee. Come, I
cannot cog and say thou art this and that, like a
many of these lisping hawthorn-buds, that come like
women in men's apparel, and smell like Bucklersbury
in simple time; I cannot: but I love thee; none
but thee; and thou deservest it.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Do not betray me, sir. I fear you love Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Thou mightst as well say I love to walk by the
Counter-gate, which is as hateful to me as the reek
of a lime-kiln.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Well, heaven knows how I love you; and you shall one
day find it.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: Keep in that mind; I'll deserve it.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Nay, I must tell you, so you do; or else I could not
be in that mind.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford! here's
Mistress Page at the door, sweating and blowing and
looking wildly, and would needs speak with you presently.

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p: She shall not see me: I will ensconce me behind the arras.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Pray you, do so: she's a very tattling woman.
What's the matter? how now!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
O Mistress Ford, what have you done? You're shamed,
you're overthrown, you're undone for ever!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: What's the matter, good Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
O well-a-day, Mistress Ford! having an honest man
to your husband, to give him such cause of suspicion!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: What cause of suspicion?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
What cause of suspicion! Out pon you! how am I
mistook in you!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Why, alas, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Your husband's coming hither, woman, with all the
officers in Windsor, to search for a gentleman that
he says is here now in the house by your consent, to
take an ill advantage of his assence: you are undone.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: 'Tis not so, I hope.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Pray heaven it be not so, that you have such a man
here! but 'tis most certain your husband's coming,
with half Windsor at his heels, to search for such a
one. I come before to tell you. If you know
yourself clear, why, I am glad of it; but if you
have a friend here convey, convey him out. Be not
amazed; call all your senses to you; defend your
reputation, or bid farewell to your good life for ever.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
What shall I do? There is a gentleman my dear
friend; and I fear not mine own shame so much as his
peril: I had rather than a thousand pound he were
out of the house.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
For shame! never stand 'you had rather' and 'you
had rather:' your husband's here at hand, bethink
you of some conveyance: in the house you cannot
hide him. O, how have you deceived me! Look, here
is a basket: if he be of any reasonable stature, he
may creep in here; and throw foul linen upon him, as
if it were going to bucking: or—it is whiting-time
—send him by your two men to Datchet-mead.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: He's too big to go in there. What shall I do?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
Let me see't, let me see't, O, let
me see't! I'll in, I'll in. Follow your friend's
counsel. I'll in.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: What, Sir John Falstaff! Are these your letters, knight?

sp.speaker: FALSTAFF
sp.p:
I love thee. Help me away. Let me creep in here.
I'll never—

p.stage: Gets into the basket; they cover him with foul linen

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Help to cover your master, boy. Call your men,
Mistress Ford. You dissembling knight!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: What, John! Robert! John!

Go take up these clothes here quickly. Where's the
cowl-staff? look, how you drumble! Carry them to
the laundress in Datchet-meat; quickly, come.

p.stage: Enter FORD, PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

sp.speaker: FORD
Servant
sp.p: To the laundress, forsooth.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Why, what have you to do whither they bear it? You
were best meddle with buck-washing.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I have dreamed to-night; I'll tell you my
dream. Here, here, here be my keys: ascend my
chambers; search, seek, find out: I'll warrant
we'll unkennel the fox. Let me stop this way first.
So, now uncape.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Good Master Ford, be contented: you wrong yourself too much.

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
True, Master Page. Up, gentlemen: you shall see
sport anon: follow me, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: SIR HUGH EVANS
sp.p: This is fery fantastical humours and jealousies.

sp.speaker: DOCTOR CAIUS
sp.p:
By gar, 'tis no the fashion of France; it is not
jealous in France.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: Nay, follow him, gentlemen; see the issue of his search.

p.stage: Exeunt PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Is there not a double excellency in this?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
I know not which pleases me better, that my husband
is deceived, or Sir John.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
What a taking was he in when your husband asked who
was in the basket!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
I am half afraid he will have need of washing; so
throwing him into the water will do him a benefit.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
Hang him, dishonest rascal! I would all of the same
strain were in the same distress.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
I think my husband hath some special suspicion of
Falstaff's being here; for I never saw him so gross
in his jealousy till now.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
I will lay a plot to try that; and we will yet have
more tricks with Falstaff: his dissolute disease will
scarce obey this medicine.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p:
Shall we send that foolish carrion, Mistress
Quickly, to him, and excuse his throwing into the
water; and give him another hope, to betray him to
another punishment?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p:
We will do it: let him be sent for to-morrow,
eight o'clock, to have amends.

p.stage: Re-enter FORD, PAGE, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p:
I cannot find him: may be the knave bragged of that
he could not compass.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: Heard you that?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: You use me well, Master Ford, do you?

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Ay, I do so.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS FORD
sp.p: Heaven make you better than your thoughts!

sp.speaker: FORD
sp.p: Amen!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS PAGE
sp.p: You do yourself mighty wrong, Master Ford.

sp.speaker: FORD
